text: Bottle. Aroma is light funky, candy sugar, floral. Taste is medium sweet, light sour. Level of sugar is to high, lack of ballance.

750 ml bottle brought back from Belgium and shared by JStax- thanks again, Jeremy! Bottled January 2009, although the label also said 37.5 cl, so Im not sure its to be fully trusted. Probably close, if not right on. It pours a cloudy copper with a finger of off-white head that settles into a ring and film. It smells like a musty gueuze, but the flavor is so different. Earth, oak, tea, tangy and lightly tart muddled fruit, dusty grains, and tons of residual sugars. Medium-plus bodied, with moderate carbonation and a sweet, lightly tart, and slightly funky mouthfeel. I forgot what a weird style this is.

750 ml bottle shared with phaleslu. The beer is a clear copper with a creamy white head of foam. The aroma has a musty, earthy acidic character to it. Upon the taste, it is something entirely different. Its like a brown sugary sweet beer. Some acidity comes through, but the sweetness is what comes through the strongest. Medium body and moderate carbonation.

Bottle. Great aroma of mix of light sourness and sugar. Smells like butter popcorn too. Taste is good, sweetness bit more there than in aroma. Good stuff though. Not much sourness but just a hint. Finish is brown sugar.
Backlog, ocena przepisana z untappd, w ramach uzupełniania profilu na ratebeer.

Well-kept 2009 edition, sampled winter 2016. Not always the best experience with long time aging of Faro but this one made it really fine. Slightly unclear golden body with almost no head at all. Nice mature aroma with smooth funk, wood and a hint of brown sugar. Flavor is sweet, but not too sweet, in fine balance with the acidity. Quite funky flavor for a Faro with just a hint of caramel, brown sugar and smooth fruity acidity. Fine balanced body and long lasting, very pleasant aftertaste that almost doesnt feel sweet at all. Very pleasant one.

Bottle shared at Johan. Brownish with off white head. Aroma is sweet & sour, candy like, brown sugar, complex acidity beneath. Taste is candy like, sweet & sour, apple, acetic, bretty, funky with some artificial sweetener in the background. Ok!

How: Bottle.
Where: Sweet & Sour 2016.
Appearance: Amber colour with no head.
Aroma: Sour, sugar, tart.
Body: Medium body and carbonation.
Flavour: Sweet, sugar, sour, some fruit.
A: Quite dark brown coloured with a white head. N: Lemon, funk, orange peel T: Red apples, orange, brown sugar O: Not my preferred style, but this one is actually nice.

Pours hazy orange with low white head. Aroma of ripe grapes, wooden barrels, sweet citrus fruit, light bretta, grass. Taste is sweet and funky with a mild tart finish. Light and smooth body with soft carbonation.

Benvit kron, små bubblor som sitter kvar efter kanten halva vägen upp, fränt! Rusar fullt upp! Syrlig söt doft, socker, röda äpplen, fräsch multnads doft! Mild surhet slåss med den goda sötman från sockret, röda äpplen & andra frukter,
Lätt kropp, som att dricka äppelmustdricka eller söt dyr päroncider

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
old bottle from 2009. pour clear and without head. light farm aromas, light fruit. taste medium sweet. the sugar taste was like glucose, a bit to much for my taste.

duft:funket syrlig sur duft. en smule frisk sødlig frugt
smag frisk sødlig med en kant af funk og en smule sur en smule smag af pære og æble

375ml bottle (thanks martjoobolut). Clear golden color. Tiny to almost no head. Acidic, nutty, yeasty, sweat, papery, farty in aroma. Sweet, honey, nutty, fruity in taste. Huhh so sweet. Too sweet for me.

375ml bottle - thanks martjoobolut!
OK, now I know that Faro is not the style for me. Pleasant sweetish aroma, some starchiness, but an nice woody aged tartness. Taste is massively sugary, not just sweet, actual sugar. Palate gently slick. Some apricottiness, some artificial sweetener bitterness, bit of apple. Sourness is nice, but sweetness kills this for me.

Bottled 2009, shared by Mart. Darkish amber beer, small white head. Nose is lemons, barnyard funk, old leaves, green apples. Flavor is tart, fruity, dry, woody, some sugary sweetness. Lingering tartness and sweet fruit, lemons. Surprisingly sweet but with a nice mouthfeel.

2009 vintage (from mikkeller webshop). Pours dark golden without head. Aroma is sour and sweet, funky, medicinal. Flavor is sweet and sour, funk, vinous notes, apple peal. Finish is sour and long sweetness. Overall: very nice.

Flaska från boxbeer.com. 2009 vintage. Orangegul mycket disig vätska med lågt skum. Stor stiltypisk geuezedoft med funk, citrus, friska äpplen, fat och lite honungssötma i bakgrunden. Riktigt välbalanserad där sötman som har drag av nektar och honung lyfter och mjukar upp smakerna men aldrig tar över. Riktigt riktigt gott. Kanske den bästa Faro jag druckigt.

Bottle @ Mikkeller Bar Aarhus. 2009 vintage. Cork is lightly moldy with some sugary leftovers. Pours hazy dark orange with a small fizzy white head. Aroma is citrussy, grapefruit soda, some moldy and funky flavours, but overall a very sugary nose with subtle citrus and green apples. Taste is very sweet and sugary. Minimal funk, light barnyardy nose, sweet green apples and grapefruit. The sweetness is really overpowering. Ill never really enjoy faro that much.

May 7, 2015. Bottle, vintage 2009 (according to the bottle...)
Hazy orange with a small off-white head. Aroma is lemon, barnyard, funk, hints of dark sugars. Taste is light to medium sweet, sour, funky, with a soft, light dry finish with lemon and wood notes. 
Light to medium bodied, small bubble carbonation.

Pours clear amber with low white head
Aromas tart of garden flowers, barnyard, earth, spices, hints of bicarbonate, sweet fruits
Taste has sour notes of bicarbonated cherries, red fruits, sour green apples

Hazy dark amber with a bubbly white head. Funky aroma with grapefruit, hay, old leaves, and a hint of vinegar. Quite sweet, but deliciously tart flavour, with plenty of funky character. It has to be one of the tastiest Faros I have had

Poured from a 375 ml bottle. 
Aroma is nice with some moderate and balanced, oak, herbal, Earth and fruit notes. Some light pineapple and citrus notes. Nice herbal, grassy character with a bit of earhty notes. 
Pours a slightly hazy, light copper color with a medium sized, moderately thick white head that recedes to a thin film that lingers for a bit. No lacing and small legs. 
Flavor has a medium light acidity with a moderate sweetness. Medium light oak notes with medium light herbal, earthy notes. Light citrus and pineapple. Hints of stone fruit. Lingering sweetness. 
Mouthfeel is medium bodied with medium to medium high carbonation. Low astringency and low alcohol warmth. 
Overall, really nice oak and herbal notes. Earthy character is nice with decent citrus and tropical fruit notes. Sweetness is a bit over the top and artificial to me, but I guess this is a bit how the style should be.

Bottle, from 09. Cork is very sugary. Pours hazy orange with nice small head. Aroma is citrusy and grapefruit, grapefruit soda. Funky and dusty, light grains, un-ripe stone fruit, candied orange. Taste is sweet at first, then turns really dry, light grapefruit bitterness in finish. Only light sugary. Peach candy, dusty, funk. Candied orange, zesty. Tart wheat.

Cask at In de Verzekering tegen de Grote Dorst - Oude faro de cam. A lovely gold with a cork sugary sweetness. Dry, light body. The taste Is tart, cork, woodsy and sweet. It pairs well with a bready traditional belgium rice pudding.
*Old rating. Bottled Jan 2009.  The beer is smooth and sourish-sweetish. Easy to drink, fresh and smooth, nice horse-blanket with a sweetish-sorish finish. Nice.

Clear golden colour, dissipating white bubbles. Aroma of apples, light sugar, some light butter. Somewhat sweet flavou, apple, light lemon zest, some funk. Finish sour apple, lambic funk. Quite fresh. Lambic with the sharp edges removed somewhat. Interesting.(From draught @ ZBF 2015, Leuven)

26/IV/15 - on tap @ day 2 of ZBF 2015 (Leuven) - BB: n/a (2015-523)  
Note: also had it at Toer de Geuze.
Clear blond to pale orange beer, small aery white head, unstable, non adhesive. Aroma: funky, brett, horse stable, cow fodder, hay. MF: no carbon, medium body. Taste: slightly sweet start, pretty bitter, funky notes, woody. Aftertaste: spicy, lemon juice, bitter, lemon peel, green apples, tart finish. Not bad!

Dark and hazy burnt orange. 1 finger head. Good cork pop. Very cheesy and brett forward. Citrus taste with for sure a little sweetness. Not a lot of depth compared to a Gueuze but thats expected with Faro. Lemon, orange, sugar. Nice beer ...cant find RBers name who shared!!! but Im so glad to have finally tried this small 37CL bottle

Taster @ the brewery De Cam, Gooik - BE. Color: clear golden beer with no carbonation and no foam. Smell: sweet notes, caramel and floral notes. Very fresh sensation. Taste: caramel and candy taste. Flowers notes. Small sour finish. Pineapple finish. Aftertaste: caramel and sour finish.
Draft at De Cam. Very grainlike at first, cookies with a special aftertaste. Gets better the more you drink, lemon, sugary, but very well balanced. Good stuff!
Shared sample at ZBF 15. Poured a Fuzzy dark golden colour with a white head. Aroma of lemons, caramel sweetness, Peach, old malts, barnyard, sweet aftertaste ofcourse. Dont like it. Sweetend lambic

UPDATED: MAY 13, 2016 Bottle 75cl bought at Beer Planet in Brussels.
Pours dark blond heading to amber; with a big dark white head.
Nose: very sweet and sour nose with lots of candy sugar, vinegar all over the place and sewer notes. Taste: the bottle says: no carbonation? Strange there is definitely carbo present. Strong sour in the beginning very very vinegar because the adding of candy sugar. The candy sugar is way to much present (not well balanced). the end is dry with notes of wood and the sugar that sticks around in my throath. I also had a sample at Zythos 2015, the Faro there was much much better. Balance was great.

375ml bottle from Mikkeller webshop. Hazy amber brown colour, white foam head and aroma of lemon rind, vinegar, funk. Taste is mellow sweetish caramel, sugary, with sour citric notes, tangy, bittersweet, plus some barnyard notes. Medium bodied, soft to medium carbonation, lingering sweet and sour at the finish. Quite drinkable.

Bottle pour, thanks to beastie. Bottled Jan 2009, I hear. Cork was a pain in the ass to get out, but Eugenes a champ (special thanks to the corkscrew). Clear dark amber pour. Head for a second, but then nothing. Aroma: Whoa, this smells like a lambic. Not what I recall from the one other faro Ive had. Big funky, lambic, tire rubber nose. Taste is sweet, but not so much that it completely overpowers the lambic funk. Medium body, soft carbonation, slick texture. Overall: sweet and funky, how could I not like this? Definitely the best of this category Ive had (granted, Ive only had one other).

375mL cork and cage. Bottled in January 2009. This is my last beer from Copenhagen haul from fall 2013. Cork would not come out. Pours with no head but still visibly carbonated. Copper amber color, clear, carbonation bubbles visible. Aroma is soooo lambicy, lots of cobwebby, dry brett (horse blanket, barn), and a decent sugar faro aspect. But the least sugar aroma of any faro Ive had. Flavor has the sugar upfront with the lambjc in the background.
user_location: HdG (past: NYC, KS, Rain City), Maryland, USA

text: Bottle in the hotel from Beer Planet. Pours clear amber with a lively and fizzy off-white head, medium-short retention with spare lacing. Aroma is sour grapes and berries with sweet malt and cellar, black walnut notes. Flavor is tart and acidic berries and grapes, light sugar notes, sweet malt, cellar and earthy yeast with stale earthy hops and a dry finish. Light body and heavy carbonation.
Hazy orange with a small white head. Aroma is sour with notes of citrus and apples. Taste is both sour and sweet.

Bottle 2009 edition. Pours slightly hazy Amber with a small white head. The aroma is barnyard, light malty, acid and light fruity. Quite sweet flavor with some acidic and leather notes. Interesting version of a Faro.

Bottle 37.5 cl from Barleywine in Copenhagen. Slightly hazy orange/brown with a thin beige head. Cherries, gooseberries, some tartness, sugary sweetness. Medium/light body, lively carbonation, sweet-tart finish. Interesting and refreshing.

Tart aroma of overripe strawberries and hints of stable. Taste is sweet and sour with a taste of cherries. The sweetness is well balanced with the sourness making it not too sweet and not to tart. Interesting with the sweetness in combination with the tartness, could have been a little less sweet though.

Bottle at home while watching some SOA. Pours nice orange with foamy head. Pleasant nose of candy and slight tart lemons. Tastes of cherry twizzlers, apricot, caramel, slight pepperiness, and some lemon Pickering. More sour than other faros Ive had but it still quite sweet especially on finish. The depth of flavors though puts this above other faros Ive had.

Bottled in January 2009. Niesamowite i odjazdowy lambick. Po glosnym wystrzeleniu korka i zadymieniu wprost z szyjki butelki 0,75 juz podczas nalewania dociera zapach wilgotnej scierki, i mokrego drewna. Pieniste niesamowicie, przy tym solidnie trwala piana, kolor bardzo metny bursztynowo-herbaciany. Zapach intensywny nieco potu i trocin, a smak niesamowicie z poczatku uderza slodycz w postaci kandyzowanego cukru potem blyskawicznie smak przestawia sie na cierpka i kwaskowa nute, do tego lekko gryzaca i goryczkowa. Doskonale zbalansowane. Rownowaga miedzy slodkosci a kwasna lambickowa octowoscia. Finisz kwasny intensywny i dlugi, lekkie nuty brazowego cukru gdzies w oddali. Swietne prawdziwe FARO. Mistrzostwo stylu, polecam jaknajbardziej.

Bottle from a beer shop in Copenhagen (which I wish I could remember!). Hazy orange pour no head. Lots of sweet spice in the nose, candy sugars and a spot of wet moss. Huge sweet n sour tang. Nice spice linger. Good stuff.
Dark golden, hazy. Has a white head, medium duration. Great mix of sweetness, sugars and acid, sulfur. Sweet flavor more acid, solvent, almost glue. Syrupy.

375 ml. corked bottle poured in to a Flute. Bottled in January 2009. Slightly hazy, deep golden colour with a bubbly, white head. Sweet aroma with a rather acidic impression: Tart apples, barnyard, bretts, vinegar, well balanced sugar, some oak. Taste is sweet with a underlying tartness. Medium body with a creamy texture and a soft carbonation. Finishes dry with candid sugar, lemons and yeasts. Excellent Faro, sugar and tart notes are really well balanced.

Tasted as unbottled forerunner at ZBF some years ago, flat and headless, with a complex lambic acidity and funkiness softened by candi sugar, as any truly authentic faro should be, more bitter in the finish. As in the 19th century when this was a daily beverage in the Brussels area, De Cam presented this home-made drink unbottled straight from tap to visitors of the festival, and started bottling it only afterwards with some alterations, so perhaps this unbottled version should be classified here as a separate entry.
light sweet sour aroma,amber, cloudy, white foam, light sweetness, lightly sour, light nice sweet sour finish. very harmonic beer.
Bottle. Frothy White fair mostly deminishing head. Amber colour. Heavy sour aroma. Moderate bitter flavior. Sour/sweet notes. Average light bitter finish. Oily palate. Fantastic beer.

750ml bottle [2009 vintage]. Clear, orangey, deep golden to amber colour with huge, effervescent, rapidly diminishing, off-white to beige head. Dry, tart, woody, slightly vinous aroma, notes of grapes, vinegar, treacle, nutmeg, cinnamon. Taste is concentrated sweet-and-sour, notes of grapes, rock sugar, balsamico, a peppery, spicy touch, some nutmeg also; dry, minimally astringent and biting. Excellent spiciness, slightly overdone sweetness, OK tartness. Im always impressed by the spicy results of the rare Faro style and particularly enthused in this case.
Poured a hazy medium yellow with a frothy white head. Aroma is musty, fusty and quite dusty, sweet fruit and sour notes. Light to medium body, flavour is moderately sweet over a tart, sour.

2009 vintage bottle shared at In De Wildeman thanks to sic1314. Pours hazy ber brown with a small off white head. Aroma is big barnyard funky, horse blanket, cobwebs and tart indistinct fruit. Flavour is moderate sweet and acidic. Full bodied with light carbonation. Overall it would be so much better without the sugar.

750mL bottle, courtesy of kraddel (thanks Dylan), pours an opaque dark orange with a small white head. Aroma brings out candied sugar, medium funk, and some slight tartness. Flavour is intensely sweet, with loads of candied sugar, very light funk, and a light tanginess. Very sugary but somehow more tasteful than most shitty faros, likely only superseded by Cantillon and 3 Fonteinens faros. Decent stuff.

Bottle, 2009 with thanks to Kraddel. Pours clear orange, large beige head that dissipates quite slowly and leaves fair lacing behind. Aroma is funk-forward, basement, dust, horse blanket, some lemon and a bit of candi sugar. Flavor is medium plus sweet, sugary, laid on top of basement funk. A light tartness takes over mid swallow and carries you toward the finish, where it is (unfortunately) met by a wave of saccharine like bitterness. Finish is pretty bad actually; dominated by an artificial sweetener aftertaste that is not appealing. Light body, high carbonation.

Bottled. Pours clear amber with a small off-white head. Aroma of brett, caramel, horseblanket and vinegar. Slightly sweet flavor that ends up dry and tart. Light to medium bodied, watery to oily texture and flat carb. A nice Lambic.

Bottle shared by esp0r with me, Simonsen & Edvard, september 28th 2013. Dark orange body, nice tanned head. Aroma of grapefruit, rubber, tart. Sweet and lactic berry taste with grass, lemons, blueveined cheese, pepper. Nice and complex, with a sour and spicy finish.
750 c&c from bu11zeye. Pours hazy copper with a beige head. Aroma is sort of sour fruit. Med body. Flavor is strawberry sweatsox with a little sour. Finishes very dry and astringent. Delicious.
Bottle shared by bhensonb. Pours amber with a modest beige head and a cereal and fruit aroma. There is a mildly sour malt flavor with a dry bitter finish. A very nice traditional faro.

Bottle... Mostly clear amber ale with a small, creamy, white head. The nose is funky, acidic and fairly acetic. Full-bodied with lively carbonation. Wow! The flavor is acutely sour and acetic up front; then tart and quite sweet on the backside. Finishes crisp and tart with lingering sweetness. Spare the sugar next time. Its why most Faros suck. This would be very nice if it was a Flanders red - although a bit too sweet for even that style - but its supposed to be a lambic. Interesting and enjoyable despite being heavy on the vinegar and sugar. Bottle courtesy of darkguardian!
Clear amber of color with an off white head. An aroma of bread, sweet and pooh. A flavor of hay, bitter, dry and sour.

Appearance: Hazy deep golden color with a frothy white head that leaves a fine lacing.Aroma: Some fusel. Acidic and fruity.Palate: Medium + body. Slightly sweet, moderate sour, mild acidic and an ok bitterness. Average carbonation. Medium dry texture.Taste: Rich fusel. Acidic, citric, sugary and mild fruity.Overall impression: I tend to like Faro a bit more than the other ones because they are a little bit more sweet.Personal stats: Bottle from Mr Kaaz

Bottled 750ml @VWPBF vintage 01/2009
Hazy amber color, small white head. Tart fruity aroma. Medium bodied. Sweet and sour - geuze and faro mix. Amazing geuze part.

Medium offwhite head. Hazy amber body with light particles.
Earthy waxy barnyard aroma with fruity notes. Sweet-acidic
fruity earthy barnyard taste with brown sugar notes. Mid-bodied.
Sharpish mouthfeel. Sweetish-acidic oily earthy barnyard
aftertaste with dried fruit and brown sugar notes. Lovely,
complex, drinkable. Perhaps the best faro Ive ever
had. (0.375l bottle, from wine monopoly, Strømmen.)

Bottle @ Home. Pours golden with a white head, lacings. Aroma of light sourness, little citrus, white sugar, little white grapes. Flavor is light sourness, little citrus,lemonpeel, white grapes, some white sugar (but not as much / bad as feared) . Medium body, soft carbonation, light acidic finish. 011113

pours hazy almost cloudy dark golden, red hue, with a bubbly white head, excellent retention and lacing. fruitiness - apricots, berries, clementines, shy but present golden candi, fruity sweetness mostly - never cloying, hint of caramel, barn and moderate funk - which is atypical for a faro as much as i know - use of oude more than probaby helps, grass and herbs. bright carbonation, light body, relatively dry bretty herbal-grassy finish. a very pleasant surprise!

Bottle (750 ml). Slightly hazy bright copper with a medium fully lasting off-white head and good lacing. Aroma is more sour than other Faro Ive had so far. Theres also some light sweetness notes and some barnyard. Taste is slightly sweet with a nice barnyard presence and some fruits. Medium body. Moderate carbonation. More complex than other Faro Ive had. Superb drinkability. Not too sweet. Loved it.

Bottle 750ml.
Pours dark amber with high creamy beige head. Intense lacing. Aroma is of funk, some fruits, barnyard. Something a tad weird, dunno what (candi?). Taste is of funk, candi, sugar. Palate: Pretty "dry" for a faro. Overall: Nice. Best Faro I had, and pretty different from others (way less unidimentionnally candied). You can feel the "oude" lambic.

Bottle. Dark copper-gold pour with nice heavy lacing. Light lambic notes, oak, light leather, pretty tame aroma. Slightly sweet flavor, you can definitely taste a bit of sugar but nothing like a regular bottle of lindemans, very well balanced sweetness and sourness. Medium bodied, med-low carbonation that gives this beer near perfect drinkability. Very tasty, this beer blew my conception of faro out of the water.

[10/9/13] Bottle on a bench outside the Royal Museum for Cental Africa in Brussels. Bottled 1/09. Hazy deep orange with a big frothy off-white head and hypnotizing carbonation. Pleasant barnyard aroma with oak, fruits and some brown sugar. Sweetish flavor with brown sugar, fruits, funky sourness, barnyard and oak. Medium-bodied. A very good Faro.

0.75l corked bottle shared with The Tasting Crew and actually courtesy of Etre. No pop in the cap, but it has a lovely big just off-white head on top of a cloudy peach orange body. Nice brett aroma with a lemon tartness, grapefruit, rice vinegar and some light candied sugar. Smells really nice this! Its definitely on the sweet faro path this one. Just about average on the carbonation with a filling mouthfeel. Lots of candied sugar here, sweet plums, something berry fruity and watery sugar syrup. The smell is super confusing compared with the taste. Smells lovely sour, tastes sugary sweet! Fruktsaft with oranges and mango in the finish. A full bottle would definitely not have been finished by me alone. 20.03.2013

Bottle shared with Simonsen, edvard & daje
Orange hazy, almost no head. Smells of the norwegian word "Gymbag", funk, smelly socks. Medium to heavy sweet, sugar syrup and candis sugar. What an extreme differense between flavor and expectations after just smelling this. Wow. Awsome aroma, not as awsome when tasted

750 ml bottle at home (taken from notes) - pours clear medium dark amber with ni head. Aroma of nuts and candi sugar, red grapes, some citrus. Medium body with still a good amount of subtle carbonation. Sweet palate and subtle sourness. Not his best beer imo but nice and easily drinkable.
Medbrakt av esp0r på hytta til dag. Lys gylden farge. Lite karbonert. Sitrus,stikkelsbær,kandis,gjær,rompesvette. Noen har tydeligvis smuglet inm denne ølen i ræva. Veldig spesiell

Bottle with friends courtesy of Aaron. Thanks man!! Pour is clear amber with a frothy cream head that quickly dissipated. Funky, green apples, pears, somewhat caramelly, bready, lemon peel aroma. Taste is is super sweet - cloyingly sweet - a touch of acid, somewhat funky, and lemon peels with a lightly tart finish. Light body with high carbonation. A complete sugar bomb and I enjoyed Girardins much more.

Pour out of 750 mL bottle, thanks Aaron! Clear orange pour with white head, aroma brings notes of vinegar, slight lactic, sugar, hints of oak, interesting. Taste is a mix of huge sugar, toffee, slight vinegar, earth, biscuit, slight oak, lemon notes, finishing fairly sweet, slightly tart.

Bottle @ Armins apartment, picked up in Bruges. Pours a hazy, bright orange appearance with a white head. Spicy, tangy, cheesy, candy sugar, light caramel aroma. Very sugar, orange candy, cheesy, caramel, incredibly sweet flavor. Jesus fucken christ this is fucken sweet.
Bottle courtesy of Darkguardian.  Clear amber pour with a white head.  Sugary malt aromas.  Thick and super sweet with sugary apple juice like notes.  Mild citrusy sub-tones.  Somewhat acidic.

Bottle 750ml @ Geokkjer
Pours slightly hazy copper with a off-white head. Aroma has notes of tart, horse blanket, brown sugar and vinegar.  Taste is light to medium sweet and medium sour. Body is medium, texture is thin to oily, carbonation is soft to flat.

UPDATED: DEC 7, 2013 Bottle. Pours deep copper with an off-white head. Aroma of brown sugar, berries, some funk and lemon. Flavor is sweet brown sugar and vinegar with some funk and wood. medium body, average carbonation.

Corked bottle, jan 09. Amber color. Oak, lemon, caramel and honey in the aroma. Sweet and sour flavor. lemon, toffee, oak. A somewhat messy heap of flavors and aromas. Too sweet for me, but a very interesting beer.

Bottle @ home.

Best Faro ive had not my fav style but this one was very nice with a good balance of sweetness and sourness.
As good as a faro gets on bottle (haven't had any on tap yet) it's hard to get your head around. I think it's good but who knows right ;)
Bottle at Bottle Shop Canterbury. Clear gold sour then sweet. Touch of glue. Yes giod unique but too sweet. Unique

bottle @ home. pours amber, small fading white foam. smell is sweet, lambic

taste is soft, very drinkable and dweet, complex. aftertaste gets more to the sour ( you can even feel this in the throat ! ) and than back to an everlasting sweetness ( realy, an hour later, still had sweetness from this) a nice example, but not THE best faro .

750 ml bottle @ WPBF 2013. Vintage 2009.
Pours a cloudy orange golden colour. Aroma of syrup, cough drops, caramel and some grass. Flavour is very strong and sour at first with notes of syrup, cough drops and hay, but after a while it turns to sweet, apple, raisiny.  Medium bodied, slick mouthfeel and medium carbonation. Rather interesting, sour and sweet at the same time. One of the best Faros Ive tasted.

[email protected]/* <![CDATA[ */!function(t,e,r,n,c,a,p){try{t=document.currentScript||function(){for(t=document.getElementsByTagName('script'),e=t.length;e--;)if(t[e].getAttribute('data-cfhash'))return t[e]}();if(t&&(c=t.previousSibling)){p=t.parentNode;if(a=c.getAttribute('data-cfemail')){for(e='',r='0x'+a.substr(0,2)|0,n=2;a.length-n;n+=2)e+='%'+('0'+('0x'+a.substr(n,2)^r).toString(16)).slice(-2);p.replaceChild(document.createTextNode(decodeURIComponent(e)),c)}p.removeChild(t)}}catch(u){}}()/* ]]> */ Orangeish deep golden colour with a small white head. Aroma is sour wood, some sugar and mild syrupy notes. Flavour is sour and tart wood, with a very sweet syrupy notes. Really dry palate. Beautiful beer.

75 cl bottle vintage 2009 @ wPBF13, bottled 01/2009
Aroma is somewhat tart and sour with grapefruit. Flavour is sweet and sour with brown sugar, earthy notes and grapefruit. Acidic finish. Confusing stuff; sour and tart but also sugary sweet at the same time.

75 cl bottle @ wPBF13.
Pours golden color with  a minimal head. Aroma of sugar, fruits and some  hay. Flavor of sugar, ripe fruits  and nettle. Weird.
3313

75cl corked and caged bottle (where oddly on the back side of the label I can clearly see this being marked as a37,5cl bottle also 2009 vintage) pick up at Beer Planet in Brussels pours with a slightly hazy pale copper body and gold edges supporting a thin light tan head of foam. The aroma is a tart fruity mix of cherries, red apple skins and lime as well as some sweetness and a soft vinegar sensation. Wow, cool taste. It begins with a vague sugary sweetness across the palate that tries in vein to cover up tart lambic tartness and sour notes. Quickly the sweetness loses out and uncovers various tart and sour notes like lime, under ripe mango and wood. Around the edges of those notes I get sugar sweetened soft vinegar mixing with faintly musty basement that never sees any sunlight and sweaty gym sock. Im digging this!

Bottle (2009, with mold on the cork!), shared with BBGTC. Pours a deep hazy orange body with a medium white head. Nose is citric acid-like vinegar notes, horseblanket, straw and hints of moss (!) and cellar must. Taste is sweet sugary tones (kind of resembling those tiny artificial tea-sweetener pills we call "sukketter" in Norway), apple cider, touches of horseblanket and hay. Medium body, high carbonation. Talk about having a massive chasm between aroma and flavor! Far too sweet and sugary for me, but not a bad example of the style I guess.

Bottle, bought @ YNWA, Kolding. Pours clear golden amber with a small, frothy white film head. Aroma has sugar, lemony, funk, tart oranges. Medium carbonation, fine dryish and light tart mouthfeel. Flavour is quite sweet, almost crunchy sugar, but with good oranges tartness. Faros are still a weird bunch, though.

Bottle: Vintage 2009:
Medium to bigger sized, pretty vast, sticky and slowly changing creamy to beige foamy head on top of a light cloudy dark yellow to amberish colored beer.
The aromas are a nice mix of cellar notes, wild yeast, wet stone, some light sour tints, pickles, clear wild wooded yeast, yeasty dust, hints of lemon and malts. 
The flavour of this beer is a lovely balanced mix of wild yeast, crispy tart, wood, malts, hint of caramel and hint of flowers, light dry, herbal, cellar stone and dust. Lovely!
Theres a medium sourness and lighter lighter, just a hint of something light sweet that gets taken over by the sournes this beer has. Nice!
Aftertaste is dry, sour, bitter, wild yeast, wood and a hint of malts. Well done.
Low to medium carbo, light dry tarty mouthfeel, medium to fuller body and a creamy texture.
Another lovely Faro! Good beer for sure!
On a side note: had some sushi with it and it suited eachother fine.
user_location: Best of E-Town mit 2 Brauhausen, NETHERLANDS

text: Bottle. Pours a golden amber with only the smallish of heads. Appears somehwat dead in the glass. Aromas are dominated by acetone and little else. Flavours show some lambic type sourness with a somehwat artifical sugary sweetness. Ok but had probably hoped for more.
Bottled. Pours amber in color thin head. Barnyard and funk in aroma. Lots of sweet barnyard and funk in taste.
.75 bottle. Copper hazy. Malts, raw cane sugar, some funk and barnyard. Body is med, sweet, a bit acidic. Very powerful, sweetish, filling. Excellent repr of the style.-- bb/h

Bottle. Pours with a orange hued body with a small white head. Aromas are funky and earthy, light cobwebs, lightly chlorophenolic rubber  notes. Flavors are nutty and funky, low sweetness, a hint of tropical fruit. Lively carbonation, thankfully not as sweet nor medicinal as some other Faros.
Pottle at Jacobs Party. Clear golden/amber - white head. Nice barnyard and sourish aroma, wooden, light fruity, ok sweetness, syrup sweet taste mixed with the sour barnyard. OK....

75cl Bottle @ home. Amber coloured with some very light carbonation and a small to non-existing white head. Sweeter light fruity lambic hinted aroma. Medium to full sprankling palate. Finish is suggary sweet with a hint of sour fruity lambic. Nice Faro.
Served in a De Cam tumbler.  Thanks, Matt.  Nose is lambic-like with slight funk and citrus but taste is harsh and a bit of a disaster. Lightly sour.

Sampled at Volkscafé De Cam.

The beer is transparent and appears amber colored with a small, fleeting head. The aroma is sweet and bready. Gueuze flavors with sugar sweetness, almost akin to a soda. Similar to other faros I have tried, especially in terms of sweetness and body. Hints of tartness come and go, but sweetness prevails. While trying these faros is fun and adventurous, I would never choose this over a traditional lambic. Well done for what it is.
Poured from a 750 ml bottle. There are dusty notes as well as citrus, acidity, not as sweet as I expected, hint  of spice, lots of funk/brett character. Very nice beer.

750 ml bottle bought online via Etre Gourmet. Pours a dark copper color with a medium white head. A really cool nose of brown sugar and big cobwebs, some really sour hints. A refreshing flavor with lots of sour sawdust, some light sugary candies, well carbonated, very good. Tasty.
Bottle.Dark amber colour with small head.Aroma of barnyard and leather,mild body and sweet with hint of sugar and acid and ripped fruits,medium body and smooth dry finish.
(Bottle) cloudy copper pour, lasting fine tan bubbles. Nose of tart/wet barrel, funky, an cranberry. Taste of tart berry, cranberry, wet barrel, funk, lemon, charred wood. This is awesome.

Bottle: Poured a light clear burgundy color lambic with a rather large foamy head with OK retention and some light lacing. Aroma consists of light barnyard notes with some light candi sugar notes and some acidic notes which can be detected. Taste is also a mix between some candi sugar though not as much as expected as overall this is quite tart. Oak notes and light barnyard notes are also discernable with acidic notes not as pronounced as the aroma was suggesting. Body is about average with good carbonation. I really enjoyed this one and this is something I would drink more often if it was available.

Bottle shared at Woodshop 7. Malty and tart, lactic and acetic, musky, woody citrus. No evidence of after-the-fact syrup addition. Not quite gueuze-like in terms of sourness but definitely in that vein, especially when compared to the saccharine quality of a Lindemanns Faro.

January 2009 Bottle date; Sampled August 2012
A steady pour into my Bruery tulip produces a two finger thick, pale tan tinged head that leaves some lacing on the sides of my glass as it subsides. The beer is a dark amber color that shows a brilliantly clear, lightly red-tinged, bright amber hue when held up to the light. The aroma smells musty, musky, funky, and sour; grapefruit zest, moldy oak, urea, a barnyard muskiness, an almost herbal woodiness, and some spicy oak character.

Amply sour, lactic and biting, a solid carbonic effervescence also adds to this. Musky, Brettanomyces, funky phenolics, touches of medicinal notes that lingers, light urea, musty cobweb notes, and old dried leather. The sourness isnt actually aggressive for a Lambic, also the overall presence of this beer disappears in the finish; there is a light phenolic character, but mostly the beer seems to disappear pretty quickly after each sip. Flavors of lemon zest, some grapefruit, touches of caramel leaning oxidation that isnt quite cardboard like, a woody flavor, and some well cured plastic like character. The body is quite light, even too light for a Lambic, it doesnt have the palate presence / slickness that a good lambic usually achieves, and I am not sure why that is. As the beer warms up the curing plastic like character gets more prevalent.

Complex tasting and interesting, I dont like that the beer seems to disappear from the palate so fast, but ultimately this does not kill the beer for me. Enjoyable, but missing that something to take it to the next level for me.
Murky amber color with tan sheen. Barnyard dung, burnt tire, dandelion aromas. Medium body. Dandelion, wet grass, pale wheat, burnt rubber, lightly tart flavors--good
user_location: Same Trailer, Different Park, Louisiana, USA

text: Orange/Amber pour.  Aroma of ruby red grapefruit, dusty yeast, and some farmy funk.  Flavor is much more sour than most faros I have had and this one is damn good! Some funk, a bit of citrus notes, yeast.

Bottle during Pauls Pre-Wedding Weekend in Belgium. Pours a light, cloudy amber with a fine white head. Tart and grassy aroma gives way to a nice, mildly sweet flavor with some toasty grass and lemons. Light to medium in body with fine, tingly carbonation. Lightly dry on the finish and very sour, with lasting tangy grass. Much better than the other faro lambics Ive had. It isnt sickly sweet at all, and the sourness is robust. Good one.

750 ml bottle

Thanks to Markus for the bottle in a trade a few months ago. I finally had a special enough occasion to share this with others. It was a fine example of a faro. I wish more breweries would give the style a try but I know why they dont. Hopefully I can find a few more myself.

Aroma / Appearance - The carbonated caramel body glimmers. There is almost no head among the tart sourness, caramel, black cherries, and Pop Tarts. The blend of sweet and sour is gentle without being sharp and intense.

Flavor / Palate - The mouthfeel is bubbly and bright. Wood, tart aspects, and the feel of a young Flemish sour perk up the senses. A great example of what traditional brewing experience can bring I wish I could have had more. While not a daily drinker it is an excellent change of pace.

Bottle at Wood Shop 7. Typical amber-orange color. Dusty nose with brown candi sugar and grapefruit. Nicely sour, a little dusty and leathery and restrained sweetness. Pretty good for a bottled faro, and more complex, though not exceptional.

750mL shared at Woodshop 7 by the bu11zeye, yespr, BMan1113VR table. Poured a low haze, deep orange. Medium carbonation. Very dark for lambic. Nose is essentially spot on De Cam with sharp grapefruit rind, moldy grapefruit, lime pulp, fresh cedar. Taste is rich, bitter grapefruit, white pepper, not really sweet like I was expecting. Different from normal faro, this is more like a normal geuze. Excellent palate- typical De Cam quenching citrus, cedar, spicy wood, sharp leather. Much better than expected.

Pours a hazy orange color with a tall tan head.  Rather funky for a Faro, but still sweet.  There is a good musty funk along with some grass, oak, nutshells, and barnyard.  The tartness is still there, underneath all the sugar.  The flavor is a nice mix of sweet and sour.  Lactic tartness with a hint of vinegar.  Sweet sugar and the nice funky notes of musty, damp oak, grass, and some barnyard.  Very enjoyable beer.
Bottle. Pours orange, with a big head. Aroma is brett, apples and fruit. Nice full body. Complex flavour with apples, honey, nuts, plums and a good oakines.
Zu Beginn ist das Bier noch säuerlich, was im Mittelteil zugunsten der auftretenden Süße intensiver wird. Süffig, hintergründig angenehm bitter-hopfig. Rund, nicht zu süß. Gut! 8/11/11/10//10

Draft @ WoSF 2012 // clear ambery orange with close to no head // wow, smell has pretty much no sugar or sweetness to it, tart, sharp, lemon, matured lambic, maybe small traces of candy sugar / taste is tart, sour, rain water, either they put very little sugar in here or they fermented most of it away, only small layer, matured lambic shines through more, acidic lemons in the finish, horseblanket & caramel, surprise how little sweetness there is in here, especially compared with other Faros // average for style body

Bottle from Dranken Geers, Oostakker, nr Gent, Belgium April 2012 consumed at home 20.05.12  Looks almost copper in colour, quite flat on the pour with no bubbles, but pretty good clarity. Wonderful aroma, I get the usual horseblanket type wafts but it is rather swamped by a wonderful vinegary salad dressing, in fact it is balsamic and a very nice one at that. Tart and sweet, this one really gives your tongue and tastebuds the most wonderful workout, your tongue will feel like its in a gym, balsamic, molasses, lemons, cane sugar it is all here. This is quite, quite lovely, tongue tingling tastic.  A8 A3 T9 P5 Ov17  4.2

Bottle shared at my 30:th birthday tasting on May 5 (30 år av Surt). Bottle bought @ Etre Gourmet. Pours hazy deep reddish golden with a rather small frothy offwhite head that quickly dissipates without leaving much trace. Smell is tiny sweet and slightly sour with hay, lemon juice, wood, leather and hints of vanilla, burnt sugar and manure. Taste is tiny sweet and sour with lemon juice, green apples, leather, grape zest, hay and hints of burnt sugar and sweat. Mouthfeel is dry, tart and medium bodied. Finish is dry and tart with grape zest, lemon zest, wood and hay.

Bottle at yespr.
Hazy orange coloured with a small off-white head.
Light acidic aroma of oak with notes of barnyard.
Sweet and light acidic flavour of caramel, oak and barnyard.
Sweet finish.

Bottle at "30 år av surt", on May 5, 2012 in Göteborg. Bottled 01/2009.
Cuivrée, col crémeux beige.
Arôme garde ce profile très lambic avec un profile sucre candi qui peine à se faire sentir. Dun côté cela démontre bien que DeCam na pas abusé du sucrose.
En bouche, le tout est sec, grains avec sucre candi, profile reste moyen en force, laissant plus le côté lambic prendre le dessus pour une pointe aigre qui reste présente, cela malgré lajout du sucre candi.

bottle shared by yespr at his place.
cloudy orange, smooth white head.
vert nice sour aroma,  quite some funk and leather, aroma does not appear sweetened. nice.
flavor is sweetened gueuze, extremelty tart and vineager note, but also quite some sugary sweet notes.

Hazy orange with a small short lasting off white head. Sweet and sour aroma with notes of wood, and hay. Sweet and sour flavor with notes og wood, Brett, lacto, wood and hay. Finished sour. lovely refreshing.

Bottled. A dark unclear amber beer with an orangey head. The aroma has notes of brettanomyces, horseblanket, sugar, and vinegar. The flavor is acidic and sweet with strong notes of sugar combined with medium notes of vinegar, caramel, malt, lemons, and horseblanket, leading to a lightly tart finish. Thanks yespr for sharing.
75 cL bottle. Pours hazy orange with a small white head. Aroma is smooth sweet toastd and citric fruity. Smooth fruity, citric and somewhat sweet. Lingering sweet and light citric finish.

Bottle 75 cl. Courtesy of yespr. Pours a lovely amber with a slight haze and a small off-white head. Lovely farty Lambic aroma. Medium body, great typical Belgian Brett accents with quite a tart edge - and then come the sugary sweetness rushing in. A Faro about as classic as they get. Yummylicious. 080512

UPDATED: MAR 22, 2014 First ratingBottle at "30 år av surt" on May 5, 20122009 vintage, looks like a 75 cl bottle but label is marked 37.5 cl.Hazy copper color, small white head. Very sour, stable, horse blanket scent. Slight bit acidic taste. Medium mouthfeel, very low bitterness.9/3/7/3/15=3.7RerateBottle 75 cl on March 14, 2014, thanks to Dunbar72! Label state Jan 2009, but also state 37.5 cl.Slight bit hazy golden color, fizzy off-white head. Vinegar, Salubrin scent. Sweet, acidic, vinegar taste. Fizzy mouthfeel, very low bitterness. Sugary aftertaste. For my taste a disgusting miw of white table sugar and vinegar aftertaste too, like an Oud Bruin on steroids, in a bad way.Not sure what the difference was between the first bottle I had and this, other than the age on them, but this time I really did not like it at all. Others at the same tasting did not mind it though, seems to be my personal preference.4/3/1/3/2=1.3
Bottle (75 cl), courtesy of _angst. Shady mahogny, medium off-white head. Earthy aroma, wood, grapefruit and barnyard. Light to medium bodied, medium carbonation. Dry with medium acidity.

(Bottle) Pours dark orange brown with a small head. The aroma holds bretty /mouldy funk, citrus, crackers, cheese and a touch of brown sugar. The flavour light sweet to dry and medium acidic with almost no bitterness with citric and bretty notes. The mouthfeel is watery and a bit tart with a light carbonation. Citric and ligt bretty finish. Light bodied.

30 år surt. Pours clear dark amber with a nice off white head leaving lace. Aroma is dry cellar sour horse stable. Flavor is sour tart dry woody in beginning, more bitter and pungent with some harshness towards the end. Finishes shortlived bitter sour and dry.

Sampled at 30åravsurt
Amber with a bubbly white head.
Sour aroma.
Very bland taste; some sugary notes.
Bottle at "30 år av surt". 2009 vintage. Amber/brown beer with a nice off-white head. Yeasty aroma, sourish. Sourish flavor, fruity, citrus.

Bottle, 2009 vintage labelled as Oude Faro, 04/29/2012.  Pours deep burnt orange, fronthy one-finger head recedes to splotchy foam on the surface, soapy lacing.  Aroma of tart stone fruit with big earthy barnyard funk, musty cheese, lemon notes on the back end.  Taste in contrast strikes as very sweet, sucrose notes dominate, behind are supporting elements of tart apples, sour malts, light barnyard with soft bitter finish.  Sweetness thickens the mouthfeel, soft carbonation.  Really had to take it slow here, the sweetness was almost too much.

Bottle 750ml.Clear medium orange colour with a average, frothy, fair lacing, mostly diminishing, off-white to white head. Aroma is moderate malty, caramel, light brown sugar, moderate barnyard, leather - horse blanket, moderateto light heavy horse blanket. Flavour is moderate sweet and light light acidic with a long to average duration. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft to flat. [20120127]

Bottle from Etre Gourmet. It pours amber, with a thick white head. The nose is floral, chamomile, tart lemon and farmyard. The taste is tart lemon, wood, white grapefruit, white grape, floral and only a touch of underlying caramel, with a rasping tart lemon finish. Medium body, lively carbonation and sharp mouth-feel. This is properly sour, unlike any other "faros" Ive had before. Much better than anticipated!

Head: none 
Colour: light cola brown 
Smell: lambic, some sugar, slight caramel, rhubarb 
Taste: slight sour in the start, bit of sweet malts and brown sugar, end is vinegary with herby notes, quite good !

Brown in color with no head (cask pulled).  Quite sweet.

Notes:  Tour de Gueuze 11
(750ml bottle)  Pours a hazy golden amber body with a small white head.  Aroma of berries, citrus, earth, sweaty feet, and cow manure.  Flavor of herbs, horsey, brett, stone fruit, and lemon.

Bottle shared during RBWG 2012. Pours a cloudy amber with a small off white head. The aroma is a fruity malt. Thin mouthfeel with a sour fruit flavor and dry finish. Easy to drink, a good faro from De Cam.
Bottle shared during RBWG 2012  Hazy dark amber with a small beige head and some lacing. Caramel. easty, barnyard and citrus. Nice.
2/25/12. Bottle shared during RBWG 2012. Hazy dark brown pour with a khaki ring. Really funky brutal yeasty aroma with a slightly tart, funky flavor. Not as sweet as I was expecting. Nice!

75cl bottle. 2011 vintage. Pours a clear burnt golden color with a medium creamy white head. Quite lasting foam. Aroma is musty and funky. Some tartness as well, but dust and must dominate, a bit of fart-like suplhur too. Taste is moderately bitter up front, slight tartness. Some funk and lemon zast. Finish is dry and leaves a bitter sftertaste which recalls burnt brown sugar. Lively carbonation and medium body. Overall, not really great, but at least the sugar does not dominate over the acidity and the overall result is quite balanced. It seems, though, as if the brown sugar adds some more off-flavors which I could push myself to appreciate completely.

Bottle @ Too many geuzes only one toilet, Ulfborg 2012. Thanks Nightfall. Pours clear dark amber with a small off white head. Barnyard and tart notes. Fart / prut. Manuer and a tart really dry flavor. One of the better Faros Ive had and by miles the best bottled one.

Bottle @ Too many Geuzes - only one toilet , Ulfborg 2012 - Day 1. Slightly hazy amber with tiny white to off-white head. Sweet malty aroma and flavour , horse blanket, stable, some lemon, a touch of brown sugar. Not as sweet as I expected it to be, quite nice.

Bottle @ fonefan tasting. Clear amber with an off-white head. Aroma is sweet, malty and moderate sour - barn. Flavor is quite sweet and moderate acidic, Rather dry and moderate acidic finish. Not as sugary as most faros. 270112

Bottle @ FOneFan. Slightly hazy amber with small off-white head. Aroma is malt, horse blanket, tart and a little leather. Flavour is malt, medium sweet, horse blanket, little tart and a little citrus.

Bottle. Pours murky brown with thin head of bubbles which quickly fade. Nose/taste is caramel, candy sugar, cane sugar, toffee, wild yeast, old wet wood, cheese and tart lemon peel. Mildly sweet with a  complex multilayer tartness that gets mellower towards the bottom. Medium body.

Aroma stald citrus grape lidt sukker: Ud.kobber klar  : Skum: hvidt korth rolig  E.smag: sød lidt sur moderat eddike Krop: medium For.: tør  Brus:livlig 
27/1-12  @ f1
Bottle @ fonefan tasting. Nice head with good duration. Color is amber. Aroma and taste are sour brett, sugar (but that much), stable, mold, malt and has a dry finish.

Th aroma isnt that bad, funky, weird, tart. Looks ok, flat, hazy amber. Mega sweet! Light sourish, maybe a hint of wood. But mainly way way way too sweet.
75cl, as De Cam Oude Faro, exclusive brew, from De Bierkoning Amsterdam, complex sweet brew, sweet/woody and slightly sour/fruity, easy to drink, balanced, cloudy, nearly no head, nice brew
No head. Smells similar as lambics usually. Taste is really sweet, and fruity. This is not sugar sweet, but fruit sweet. Nice, very nice.
Fra fat på Geuzestekerij De Cam i Gooik under Tour de Geuze 1 Mai 2011. Gyldenbrun. 0 skum. Tung fruktaroma. Smaken bra avrundet med litt krydder og frukt. Litt syrlighet i ettersmaken.

On tap at the blender. Its an unclear, golden-orange beer with some bubbles trying to form a head. Cellar, lemon juice and some woodish notes on the nose. The flavor is mostly on the sour side, with just a touch of sugar. Medium to full body, dry. A nice beer indeed, very dry and sour for a faro, certainly a beer Id like to repeat. 110501

UPDATED: APR 24, 2017 On tap at the brewery. Golden color with no head. Aroma is sweet, sour, sugar, yeast. Flavor is sweet, sour, sugar, yeast, dust, apple. OK/Nice beer. 6-3-6-3-13. Tasted again 021216 one 2009 edition. wood and more pleasant. Very nice.

Served chilled from a bottle at the microbrewery. Amber, slightly hazed. Naked on the surface. Dusty and citric fruity nose. Earth, herbs, and tart apples to the taste buds. Smooth and dry tail (Toer de Geuze, Gooik 01.05.2011).

Draft at the source, Tour de Geuze 2011.  Cloudy variegated golden amber color, no head or lacing.  Sour and caramel together, with no overt sweetness, but with some white pepper, citrus, apricot.  Outstanding.
Dark orange and very unclear. Smells of apple and cherry. Fruity taste with notes of brown sugar and sweet berries. Not too sweet though. Hop dryness in the middle and fruity end. Very nice faro!

On tap at 1ste BAB-Bierfestival, Brugge. Hazy deep golden colour, a small rim of froth. Pleasant and complex acidic-sweet aroma. Sweet toffee with an acidic bite. Fruity. Dry finish. Highly drinkable and suggesting greatness to come.

On tap at Bab festival. Pours golden orange color, with almost no head. Aroma spicy, sweet malts. Medium body. Taste some lemon notes, sweet malts, and sourness. 
Good.

Sampled from draught at De Nacht van de Grote Dorst 2006.Muddy orange appearance, almost no head. Grapefruity slightly acidid aroma with a sour edge. Woody hints. Flavor is sweet and sugary at first with a fresh sourish lemon note showing up. Very smooth with an excellent drinkability, almost lemonady. A really good faro.
Draught @ Grote Dorst 2006. Hazy orange colour with a small head. Sweet sugar in the aroma with some hints of sourness. Flavor of brown sugar with some hints of acidity. Slightly sweet finish.

Draft. Cloudy gold. Nose is light sugary notes, faint sour fruits, and light earthiness. Taste is sweet-sour fruits, light leather, sweat, mild litterbox, and some pleasant sugary notes. Body is light and crisp. Finishes sweeter with light sourness, mils leathery notes and faint barnyard.
Draught (ZBF06): Sweet brown sugar in the aroma and flavour. Mild citric flavour with some sour grapes. Not bad.

UPDATED: MAY 8, 2012 Rerate: Brownish coloured. Unclear. Sour aroma with a sweet touch. Has hay, wood, some brett and grape in the flavour. Medium to full bodied. Ends on a quite grapish sweetness. Easy to drink. 
Draught @ Grote Dorst 2006: Brown coloured. Unclear. Small head. Sweet and fruity nose. Has some vinegar notes. Flavour of cold tee. Some sweetness, some acidity and some fruityness. Is grapish and citric. ENds on a light sweet note. 7-3-8-3-15

Tap, ZBF 2005. Hazy gold, thin white head and low condition. Tart nose verging on vinegar with some citrus notes, Sweet and thin in the mouth with a gentle quenching tartness. Short, watery and sweet finish.
Draught at ZBF 2005  Sparkling, orange body.  No head.  Cask-aroma.  Lightly sweet, lightly acidic initial flavour.  Lightly acidic finish.  Flat carbonation (off course).  A very lovely faro!
Sweet, acidic, vinegary, earthy aroma. Dark golden colour, no head. Very little carbonation. Sweet acidic flavour.
Zythos Beer Festival, Sint-Niklaas, Belgium 2005. Golden colour with a no head. Light sour lemon aroma and sweet sour taste. Medium to full body and a sweet sour finish.

Draught at ZBF 2005. Pours golden brown, with no head. Aroma is sweet, spicy, with somw brett. Taste is sweet from the sugar, with some lemon notes. In the aftertaste, the sweetness fades, and leaves sour notes
Darker blond lambic with no head and almost no carbonation. Rather weak light sweet-sour aroma. In the taste I get apple, lemon and pine needles. The sweetness is interestingly odd.

Draught  Slightly hazy, pale amber; small, very airy, nearly transparent head. Sweet dark candi syrup nose, mixed with lemon and lemonpeel; leathergrease & Brett. Tart despite the sugar, some exotic fruit, grapefruit, lemon. Very nice, dry, and horsey finish. Light, certain slickness from the syrup. Very good faro. I know gueuze that is less authentic than this.
